title: What will be the valuation of Snap Inc following its initial public offering?
possible_answers: More than $30 billion but less than $40 billion
preds:
Snap Inc's (SNAP.N) shares ended up 44 percent on their first day of trading as investors flocked to buy into the hottest technology stock offering in three years, overcoming doubts about the loss-making messaging app company's slowing user growth. The stock closed at $24.48 on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, well above the initial public offering price of $17 per share on Wednesday, giving the company a market value of $28.3 billion, on a par with CBS Corp (CBS.N) and Target Corp (TGT.N). At one point the stock hit a high of $26.05 and a market value of $29.1 billion.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-idUSKBN1690I7?il=0
confused by bloomberg's market cap reporting and the clarification, and the commonly advertised formula for calculating market cap from market shares.
I think my math is correct, outstanding shares x price per share. $24.73 * $661.87MM = $16368.0451MM or $16.368
Looks like I'm calculating the market cap wrong according to bloomberg.
At current trend it will still close at just over 21 billion.

At $17 a share, the parent of popular disappearing-messaging app Snapchat has a market valuation of roughly $24 billion
http://in.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-idINKBN1683BP

Snapchat Parent Snap Set to Price IPO Above Projected Range
Shares set to price at $17 each, valuing firm at $24 billion in biggest U.S. tech debut since Alibaba
https://www.wsj.com/articles/snapchat-parent-snap-prices-ipo-above-projected-range-1488400583 Insanely overpriced.
Overcorrecting due to more recent news. https://www.wsj.com/articles/snapchat-parent-snap-prices-ipo-above-projected-range-1488400583
I'm not sure about this one.

Slightly adjusting my estimate upwards not due to the actual value of the company, but how the IPO is structured. Details suggest that 25% of the IPO is being offered to existing institutional investors and will be subjected to a 1-year lockup. Other large investors will be subject to a shorter lockup period. This may decrease quick profit-grabs and opening-day price volatility. https://www.wsj.com/articles/snap-on-cusp-of-ipo-looks-set-for-strong-debut-1488364204

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-idUSKBN1683BP
Still not convinced they'll get to $20B, but this has been a bad year to bet against the lemmings.

Media speculation that looking to price above existing range at US$17-18/share. Assuming this is correct and not just bankers talking up the price. The market cap will almost certainly be above $20bn (although remember FB was flat on day 1 after pricing above the range.) Cutting likelihood that it will be below this level. Raising possibility of very strong first day performance.

Snap shares set to price above range due to investor demand
Final price for company behind messaging app expected to be between $17 and $18
 A price of $17-$18 would put Snap’s market capitalisation at $19.7bn-$20.8bn. Final pricing is expected on Wednesday.
https://www.ft.com/content/aebaaf36-fe0b-11e6-8d8e-a5e3738f9ae4#comments

Lock-up periods help companies moderate stock volatility by preventing company insiders from selling their shares within an allotted time. A year-long lock-up period is atypically long, potentially signifying strong demand for the IPO. Snap is targeting a valuation of between $19.5 billion and $22.3 billion from listing on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday. It is looking to price 200 million shares on Wednesday night at a range of $14 to $16 dollars a share. Orders for the IPO have begun to come in at the high-end of its range, and its "book" is already oversubscribed, according to people familiar with the process who requested anonymity. 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-idUSKBN16703K No shortage of foolish sheep who are going to be shorn.

From latest prospectus filing, expected share count after IPO is 1,157m (excluding greenshoe). I'm not completely confident this will be the actual number given the RSUs, options etc outstanding, but it is the figure given for the adjusted pro forma...There is also a risk that the offer size is increased or decreased.
Current price range is $14-16 implying a value of $16.2-18.5bn.
As someone else states, this is now about pricing rather than valuation. The bankers will have done pre-marketing and should (may) have a reasonable idea on demand at different valuations, but won't know for certain until the orders come in. The $14-16 range will have been set so that they have a good chance of pricing at or above the top end.
At the top of the range, only an 8% jump on day 1 is needed to reach $20bn. First day performances for big tech IPOs have been mixed FB was flat after the first day despite pricing at the top of an increased range, while Linkedin +109%, Twitter +73% and Alibaba +38% performed well. Basically, if the IPO is a "success", Snap will be valued at more than $20bn end day 1. An outside chance valued at more than $30bn.
My subjective view is that investors may be wary given highly publicised governance issues and concerns that it is another Twitter. It doesn't feel like there is a lot of excitement about the offer. Not immaterial chance that IPO is a "failure" i.e. priced at bottom of the range, flat on day 1 etc. Unlikely to drop below final IPO price on day 1 with underwriters "stabilising" the price.
Rumours about how the roadshow is going may give insight but may be bankers trying to talk up demand. Obviously a market decline could have an impact on price, although a major fall means the IPO would probably be pulled.

Initial price range is around 20 billion dollars. Net losses of half a billion, impressive growth numbers, but growing competition from companies with more financual power: Facebook and Google. No proof for having a sustainable Business model (Twitter!). Economic conditions are good, People like tech companies and long for IPO-Event.

WhatsApp launches Status, an encrypted Snapchat Stories clone
https://techcrunch.com/2017/02/20/whatsapp-status/

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-idUSKBN1602UM
There are many imponderables about Snap.  In general the markets are okay with uncertainties but not with imponderables.
They are bleeding money, and cash flow isn't exactly stellar. The market sentiment is not too strong on Snap's strength.

1) The intrinsic value is certainly less than $20 billion. 2) The current offering  is $3bn for 15% and since the question focuses on valuation which takes price into consideration which in turn depends on investors' future expectations of Snap.

Snap arrives in London to woo skeptical investors ahead of IPO Some fund managers have said they will stay away from Snap given its decision to adopt a three class share structure - the first of its kind - that will mean shareholders who buy in through the IPO will not have any voting rights. Instead Spiegel and his co-founder Bobby Murphy will have the right to 10 votes for every share, and existing investors one vote for each of their shares. "My view would be investors should tread with caution here, the fact the shares will carry no voting rights would be a major concern for me from a governance perspective," Richard Saldanha, global equities fund manager at Aviva Investors, said ahead of the roadshow. Aviva manages 318 billion pounds across a range of asset classes. Mike Fox, head of sustainable investments at Royal London Asset Management, said the inability to vote against a company at its annual general meeting was a "major red flag" and he would not be taking part in the IPO.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-idUSKBN15Z1SI?il=0
Up on recent news. I hope this means post-money.

Continuing to lower my expectations. Update from WSJ about Spectacles possibly ending up with the same fate as Google Glass. Novelty of the product is waning and early adopters have cut down on use. Also, WhatsApp is now copying Snapchat's disappearing 24 hour post idea. https://www.wsj.com/articles/snap-tries-to-jump-start-spectacles-sales-as-novelty-fades-1487595600
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/20/technology/whatsapp-status-facebook-snapchat.html

The current fully diluted market cap estimation is $20-23b. An embedded greenshoe option should ensure that the closing price will not be below the IPO price. They may yet lower the IPO price if they feel there is a lack of demand, but in any case there should be plenty of upside potential and little to no downside, regarding the closing price. IPOs of other SNS's have seen very strong end of day gains (Twitter, LinekdIn). Good overall analysis here http://www.goodwatercap.com/thesis/understanding-snapchat/
Assesment (lots of numbers) of the value of Snap: http://aswathdamodaran.blogspot.nl/2017/02/a-snap-story-valuing-snap-ahead-of-its.html 'bankers don't value companies; they price them!'

Snapchat lowers expectations to 16 to 18.5, but strategies to hit 22+ are thought to be possible:
https://www.ft.com/content/f31e123a-f41a-11e6-8758-6876151821a6

However it said on Thursday it was targeting a valuation between $19.5 billion and $22.3 billion, ahead of an investor roadshow due to start on Monday in London.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-valuation-idUSKBN15V0JK
Based on secondary information and as a Snapchat user
decreasing based on latest sec filings  http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-valuation-idUSKBN15V0JK

Big change from prior. In the filing they use a $16 maximum offering price and talk of a teen billion valuation (which suggests significant investor pushback). Tricky b/c the basic shares outstanding will be closer to 1bn while diluted may be closer 1.3bn. I assume the valuation question is ultimately based on diluted S/O

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-valuation-idUSKBN15V0JK
They are coming in at $16-$18.5B at the moment.  This is rather a distance from $20B, but this may be a ploy of some sort.  Not that large corporations would ever dream of misleading mislead investors or consumers, of course.

The main reason why I have decided to give these result is because of the recommendations and expectations on the valuation of Snap Inc. The forecast valuation of the experts is between $20-25 Billions. 
Furthermore I have done research about other IPO of tech-companies and as an example Facebook was valued before the IPO between $77 billions - $96$ billions and but at the end of the IPO the valuation of the company ended in $104 billion. This increase in price was due to the high demand, suggesting that Facebook could have choose a relatively higher offering price. Analyzing my prospects and the result of Facebook IPO could lead to say that my predictions are wrong but it has to be understood that Facebook and Snap Inc. are in different stages as companies as Facebook wasn’t that new in comparison to Snap Inc. and the its why I haven’t give a bigger percentage to the probability of being valued over $30 billions. 
Moreover as the company is not publicly trade its  difficult to know the investment of it and how are its financial statements, for this reason setting a higher valuation is to risky as Snap Inc. is a company that doesn’t like to share company information.
Another fact to support my estimations is because the book value of the company is much lower than experts estimations (but we all know that the book value doesn’t have to meet the market value).
Lastly in 2012 Facebook tried to acquire the whole company offering $3 billions which helps to see that the company doesn’t worth more than $30 billion but it could be between $20 - $30 billions or less as in 4 years the company brand, acknowledgment and value could have increased in this amounts.  
For all this reasons I believe that Snap Inc. value would be between $20 - $30 billions or less than $20 billion.

Snap Inc. set the valuation on its initial public offering at between $19.5 billion and $22.2 billion in what could be the third-biggest technology offering of the past decade, people familiar with the matter said.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-02-16/snap-said-to-set-ipo-valuation-at-as-much-as-22-2-billion

In order to issue shares with no voting power, of a company with fragile business model which lacks revenue diversification, requires substantial price discount. Expected valuation already came down from $25bn to $19.5bn. Personally I believe there is still more room for valuation to come down because even though the revenue per customer rose by $0.31 from a year earlier, net loss deepened as well by $142m. This shows that it is very hard to attract new business without maintaining reasonable deficit.

Snap Inc, the owner of the popular messaging app Snapchat, has set a valuation range for itself of $19.5 billion to $22.2 billion in its initial public offering, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources.
http://uk.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-valuation-idUKKBN15V0JK
Instagram is catching up, proposing the same features. they also have more active users, and broader age range. Snap is for more for millenials...

Additional information about the Snap IPO. The company values itself at $16.33/share, or approx $21.6 billion. The WSJ blog details numerous potential risks, including a net loss of -$514.6 million despite growth of sales to $404.5 million, increased costs due to its reliance on Google Cloud, lack of long-term advertisers, and reliance on the 18-34 crowd which is historically less brand-loyal.  Ultimately, it boils down to how much faith do you have in its founder, Evan Spiegel, to continue revenue growth, control costs, and counter Facebook moves. http://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2017/02/02/snaps-ipo-filing-everything-you-need-to-know/

“Snap will be one of the anchor tenants,” he said. “Their valuation shows you can build and scale in LA. Even if they don’t get $25bn, even if they get $15bn, it will be an awesome success story for the city.”
https://www.ft.com/content/a7b45316-ef44-11e6-930f-061b01e23655
Unfortunately, even for a loss-maker, inflated IPO valuations are symptomatic of late-cycle IB behaviour. We've seen this all before.

Snap Inc values itself at $25 billion, but given its user base, competitors, intended equity offer (non-voting shares) and clouded prospects, there is a high probability the value is less than $20 billion following its IPO.

1. There is quite a bit of interest in the stock with strong liquidity in the market 2. There have been few new issues recently 3. The total number of listings is low relative to the last 10 years but beating Alibaba IPO will be a stretch.

One of my favorite info sources justifies the target 20-25B valuation ( https://www.cbinsights.com/blog/snapchat-valuation-ipo/ ).  I give 5% of less than that range to take into account a Trump news bomb happening on that day.  A 5% chance of doubling the low end of the stated range based on excitement for the next social media ipo.

there are few fundamentals to focus on with this business - as with past unicorns, the valuation seems to be driven by two factors - (1) "build it and they will come" - in other words, build the social network, attract the user base, then worry about how to monetize it, and (2) a fear of missing out - prevalent in the great dotcom bubble and once again a driver.  both factors contribute to valuation being talked up and thereby becoming a self fulfilling prophesy - so my forecast will change as the prevailing coverage in the financial press/blogs etc moves about.
I could summarize the answer with two words that encompass all these options: Too high. But most of the information I have seen has placed an estimated valuation of $25 billion.
With their present target around $20 Billion, no bad for a company that loses around $200 million and has no prospects of making money in the next five years, so there!
Read chwang's forecast explanation and blended with mine which is far less certain. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/440265

Snap IPO will not go off well. Questions about growth vs. Instagram and also no voting rights will weigh on valuation. Ironically it will resemble the Facebook IPO. Pundits will compare Snap to Twitter.

Current estimates for the IPO are as high as $25b. If we use Snap Inc.'s estimate of $1b earnings for 2017, That translates to an potential earnings multiple of 25x. These were the potential earnings multiple of recent tech companies IPOs:
Facebook - 19.4
Twilio - 18.3
Twitter - 13.0
Alibaba - 12.7 Snap Inc faces several major obstacles as a business, which may temper investor expectations:
1) It's main business relies heavily on Snapchat's ad-driven revenue
2) Snap competes directly with Facebook, which added Instagram Stories feature in August 2016 that provides a similar vanishing 24 hr image service
3) Snap users spend an average of 10 min/d on the site. Facebook claims Instagram users spend 20 min/d (though a Cantor Fitzgerald analysis suggests it is 6 min/d - the truth is likely somewhere in between).
4) Snap recently rebranded itself as a "camera company" and selling camera-enabled sunglasses. But at $129.99 I don't see it moving out of a niche market. Facebook announced in Nov 2016 that it would focus on becoming a "video-first" company in direct competition to the Snap Spectacles.
5) Perhaps most importantly, the Snap IPO is strongly considering offering only class A (non-voting) shares. This may result in the IPO trading at a discount since it means the company's success will depend entirely on current management's ability to counter its rivals' (e.g. Facebook) strategies. Historically, non-voting shares trade at a slight discount vs. voting shares (mean discount of -2.9%) but Facebook's size & nimbleness, I believe this discount will likely be larger. Therefore, I predict the most likely first day IPO valuation will be:
$1 billion (predicted 2017 earnings) x 15.9 (mean future earnings multiple from above) x 0.97 (less historic 3% discount) = $15.4 billion https://www.bloomberg.com/gadfly/articles/2016-10-07/snapchat-ipo-5-charts-explaining-why-it-s-worth-25-billion
https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-rivals-shadow-looms-over-snapchat-ipo-1486296005?tesla=y
https://qz.com/901904/will-snapchat-snap-investors-get-voting-rights-with-their-ipo-shares/
Basically following Raahul_Kumar. I'm not bullish on Snap at all; don't use it; don't understand Snapchat's appeal in the first place.
Not a big believer in Snap, but my guess is that there's been a lot of ground work on anchoring of the $25bn figure.

Probably the most startling aspect of the Snap filing is the presentation of the financial results for the last two years. Snapchat made US $404,482 in revenue for 2016 with costs of US $924,867. Specifically, its cost of revenue was US $451,660. In other words, unless Snap can find a way to make more money out of each of its existing users, it is never going to make money. Snap says as much when it states in its filing:     “We have incurred operating losses in the past, expect to incur operating losses in the future, and may never achieve or maintain profitability”
https://theconversation.com/snapchats-ipo-filing-does-nothing-to-justify-its-us-25-billion-valuation-72473

A big problem of snap inc is the profit margin, snap inc earned per user round 2$ while facebook erne 20$. The other problem is the big competitor instergram ( bought from Facebook ). And last the high expenditure for ther servers from google ( expectation $2 billion for 2017).
I think they will not hit ther target of 25 billion  I'm open to objection what do you think?????????? :-)
Internet Bubble 3.0 $30 billion? That is an absurd valuation that Snapchat can never make good on.
I am out of my league in this question and until we know more I going with their goal of around 25.

Snap S-1 filing not overly impressive:
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-costs-idUSKBN15I2YV?il=0
https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1564408/000119312517029199/d270216ds1.htm Lack of shareholder voting rights is also a current concern in the investment community.  Some analysts claim to reduce IPO prices, in general, by 30% based on lack of shareholder voting rights.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-snap-ipo-votingrights-idUSKBN15I2W7?il=0
I worry IPO gets postponed and in between some important factors will change thus the valuation will have to change.
Only read first article. Low certainty estimate.
